column3: French: [myze dɔʁsɛ]) is a museum in Paris
column5: on the Left Bank of the Seine.  It is housed in the former Gare d'Orsay
column6: a Beaux-Arts railway station built between 1898 and 1900. The museum holds mainly French art dating from 1848 to 1914
column10: and photography. It houses the largest collection of Impressionist and post-Impressionist masterpieces in the world
column19: and Van Gogh.  Many of these works were held at the Galerie nationale du Jeu de Paume prior to the museum's opening in 1986. It is one of the largest art museums in Europe. Musée d'Orsay had more than 3.6 million visitors in 2019.

column1: The museum building was originally a railway station
column3: constructed for the Chemin de Fer de Paris à Orléans and finished in time for the 1900 Exposition Universelle to the design of three architects: Lucien Magne
column4: Émile Bénard and Victor Laloux. It was the terminus for the railways of southwestern France until 1939.

column1: By 1939 the station's short platforms had become unsuitable for the longer trains that had come to be used for mainline services. After 1939 it was used for suburban services and part of it became a mailing centre during World War II. It was then used as a set for several films
column2: such as Kafka's The Trial adapted by Orson Welles
column3: and as a haven for the Renaud–Barrault Theatre Company and for auctioneers
column4: while the Hôtel Drouot was being rebuilt.

column2: permission was granted to demolish the station but Jacques Duhamel
column4: ruled against plans to build a new hotel in its stead. The station was put on the supplementary list of Historic Monuments and finally listed in 1978. The suggestion to turn the station into a museum came from the Directorate of the Museum of France. The idea was to build a museum that would bridge the gap between the Louvre and the National Museum of Modern Art at the Georges Pompidou Centre. The plan was accepted by Georges Pompidou and a study was commissioned in 1974. In 1978
column5: a competition was organized to design the new museum.  ACT Architecture
column6: a team of three young architects (Pierre Colboc
column8: were awarded the contract which involved creating 20
column10: 000 sq ft) of new floorspace on four floors. The construction work was carried out by Bouygues. In 1981
column11: the Italian architect Gae Aulenti was chosen to design the interior including the internal arrangement
column13: furniture and fittings of the museum. In July 1986
column14: the museum was ready to receive its exhibits. It took 6 months to install the 2000 or so paintings
column15: 600 sculptures and other works. The museum officially opened in December 1986 by then-president François Mitterrand.

column2: the Musée d’Orsay is scheduled to undergo a radical transformation over the next decade
column3: funded in part by an anonymous US patron who donated €20 million to a building project known as Orsay Grand Ouvert (Orsay Wide Open). The gift was made via the American Friends of the Musées d’Orsay et de l’Orangerie.

column1: The square next to the museum displays six bronze allegorical sculptural groups in a row
column2: originally produced for the Exposition Universelle:
